moves.1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. Bc4: have no worries: White has not lost her mind; we are playing what we used to call 'Take Away Chess': in this type of chess, capture is mandatory; so after d5, exd5, Qxd5, were forced moves: now, Black has to capture; but he has multiple choices...
moves.3... Qxd2+: getting rid of major pieces is always a good thing: after Qxg2 or Qxc4, Black would force himself into a difficult position...
moves.4. Bxd2: taking the Queen is forced: we have to capture and get out of check at the same time; White decides to keep the Queen out of play...
moves.4... b5: cleverly done: after Bxb5+, Black can offer some more material...
moves.5. Bxf7+ Kxf7: but Black has to capture and solve check...
moves.6. Qg4 Bxg4 7. Bh6 gxh6 8. h3: time to explain the object of this game: the winner is the player, that has only the King left; with all other pieces gone - hence take away chess - and not in check or mate: or the player, that mates the other one; mate is still possible...
moves.15. Nxa7 Rxd2 16. Kxd2 Nf6: Blacks' pieces are getting out of Whites' reach...
moves.17. Nxb5 Rd8+ 18. Ke3: Nd4, Rxd4, would cost another piece: but White switches to a different game; exhaust all Blacks' moves...
Black has nearly won this game: but how to get rid of h7?
moves.25... hxg3 e.p. 26. Re1 g2 27. Re3 g1=Q: Black is confident, he can ditch the Queen at some point...
